The phonologisation of /æ/ was mostly a collateral effect of the merger of some other sounds: Danish æ /ɛː/ vs. e /eː/ and sj /sj/ vs. rs /ɐ̯s/ have come to be pronounced in the same way in Norwegian (respectively /eː/ and /ʂ/)

Grammatical differences IPA Nominal morphology Gender Danish has two grammatical genders – common (indefinite article en and definite article -en) and neuter (indefinite article et and definite article -et). In Norwegian
column166: the system is generally the same
column167: but some common words optionally use special feminine gender declension patterns
column168: which have been preserved from Old Norse in Norwegian dialects and were re-introduced into the written language by the language reforms of the early 20th century. Hence
column169: three genders are recognized – masculine (morphologically identical to Danish common
column170: with indefinite article en and definite article -en)
column171: feminine (indefinite article ei and definite article -a) and neuter (morphologically identical to its Danish counterpart
column172: with indefinite article et and definite article -et
column173: pronounced /ə/). The likelihood of a feminine as opposed to common form being used depends on the particular word
